Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the extent to which a full-time worker earning minimum wage in 1968 could support a family of three above the poverty line.
Understate: The claim may be understating the current earning of a full-time worker earning minimum wage, suggesting that they earn less than the poverty line for a family of two.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the minimum wage in 1968 was applicable to all workers, without acknowledging the bifurcation of minimum wages at that time.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or data to support the assertion that a full-time worker earning minimum wage in 1968 could support a family of three above the poverty line.
Exist alternative explanation: There may be alternative explanations for the changes in the minimum wage and poverty thresholds over time that are not addressed in the claim.
